abstract.p: Though biological consequences of CCS (Carbon Capture and Storage) implementation into the marine environment have received substantial research attention, the impact of potential CO 2 leakage on benthic infauna in the Baltic Sea remained poorly recognized. This study quantified medium-term (56-day laboratory exposure) effects of CO 2-induced seawater acidification (pH 7.7, 7.0 and 6.3) on energetic reserves and heat-shock protein HSP70 expression of adult bivalve Limecola balthica from the southern Baltic. While no clear impact was evident in the most acidic treatment (pH 6.3), moderate seawater hypercapnia (pH 7.0) induced elevated catabolism of high caloric reserves (carbohydrates including glycogen and lipids) in order to provide energy to cover enhanced metabolic requirements for acid-base regulation. Biochemical response did not involve, however, breakdown of proteins, suggesting that they were not utilized as metabolic substrates. As indicated also by subtle variations in the chaperone protein HSP70, the clams demonstrated high CO 2 tolerance, presumably through development of efficient defensive/compensatory mechanisms during their larval and/or ontogenic life stages.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Sub-seabed Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS) is regarded a mitigation technology for the reduction of CO 2 emissions. In the Baltic Sea, the oil-carrying field B3, which is currently operated by the state-owned oil-exploiting company GRUPA LOTOS S.A., is considered to provide an important sink for geological storage of CO 2 . The oil reservoir is located at water depth of 80 m and under the seabed depth of 1450 m in the Polish sector of the Baltic (the Polish Exclusive Economic Zone). The storage is expected to conduct from the existing petroleum platforms in potential conjunction with CO -enhanced oil recovery (EOR). The CO 2 stored in the B3 field is planned to include compressed refinery generated gas (c.a. 450 kt year -1 ) and supercritical CO 2 fluid from the planned IGCC Powerplant (1Mt year -1 ). What is more, after the end of natural gas exploitation, two other neighbouring fields B4 and B6 in the same water-basin may also offer potential capacity for additional CO 2 storage. Both oil and gas fields are located in the tectonically stable area which is covered with the Silurian deposits of thickness ranging from 1000 to 2000 m which shall prevent CO 2 leakage (Zajfert et al., 2015). Sequestration of CO 2 under the sea floor in depleted/exploited oil and gas reservoirs in the Baltic has been included into long-term strategy of Grupa LOTOS S.A. and the Baltic Sea CO 2 Storage project (BASTOR 2) within the BASREC CCS Network (the Baltic Sea Region Energy Cooperation) (http://basrec.net). The technology is in line with the EU strategy on reduction of CO 2 emission and energy policy of Poland which, according to the CCS Directive of the European Parliament and the Council of Europe 2009/31/WE on geological storage of CO 2 and later directives, is required to reduce substantially anthropogenic CO 2 emission in the coming years. Though sub-seabed CCS is considered as a feasible option and depleted oil and gas reservoirs have usually sufficient seal integrity, storing large volumes of liquid CO 2 raises concerns about environmental risk assessment related to CO 2 leakage from a storage reservoir, its spatial and temporal evolution and effects on the marine environment. Amendments to the London Protocol and OSPAR agreement require that measures for discovery and elimination of possible leaks from sub-M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 4 seabed CO 2 storage sites should be taken before CO 2 storage activities are initiated. The OSPAR Guidelines for Risk Assessment and Management of Storage of CO 2 Streams in Geological Formations asks for the "improvement of impact prediction by gaining knowledge on the effects on species and ecosystems as a result of leakage of CO 2 " (OSPAR, 2007). In the brackish Baltic Sea, CCS has not been implemented yet and the potential impact of CO 2 leakage on the marine ecosystem can be assessed only based on laboratory studies (e.g. Jansson et al., 2013Jansson et al., , 2016Jakubowska and Normant-Saremba, 2015;Sokołowski et al., 2018) or research field experiments in fully-saline water-basins (e.g. Lichtschlag et al., 2015).

A major consequence of seepage from the sub-seabed storage site is severe seawater acidification which is likely to lead to localized effects on the seafloor (Blackford et al., 2009;Murray et al., 2013). Although such effects are spatially constrained, significant point-source leak will affect neighbouring areas creating a pH gradient in the near-bottom zone, thus influencing gradually benthic organisms (Baxter et al., 1989). Controlled laboratory experiments (e.g., Lee et al., 2016), exposure experiments in situ (e.g., Ishida et al., 2013) and studies at natural CO 2 seeps (e.g., Allen et al., 2017) have been therefore performed in a range of seawater acidity to assess biological responses under various leakage scenarios and under different pH conditions (e.g., CO2MARINE; ECO2, 2014). The general mechanisms proposed through which CO 2 leakage could impact benthic species and communities (for review see Kroeker et al., 2013) are not, however, necessarily uniform across different taxa or environmental conditions (Walther et al., 2010). For example, divergent patterns of compensative/defensive biological traits and metabolic performance were documented for the Baltic clam Limecola (former Macoma) balthica from the brackish non-tidal southern Baltic Sea. The bivalve demonstrated behavioural and physiological responses as well as reduction in shell growth at seawater pH 7.0 while responses to more acidic conditions (pH 6.3) were mitigated. This indicated a high tolerance of this species to severe hypercapnia presumably stemming from its adaptation to natural variations in interstitial water CO 2 concentration associated with the mineralization of sediment organic matter (Sokołowski et al., 2018). In addition, low salinity and water temperatures in the Baltic

div.p: Sea, and a subsequent decrease in concentration of Ca + and HCO 3 -, which are relevant for calcification, may impose constraints on calcification and shell dissolution (Thomsen et al., 2015). Special caution is therefore advised when inferences about the effects of seawater acidification on Baltic benthic species are drawn based on results from other coastal areas (Havenhand, 2012). So far, research of the impact of increased seawater acidity due to potential CO leak on marine invertebrates in the Baltic has not been performed except the very recent study of Sokołowski et al. (2018). Together with increasing demand for commercial-scale CO 2 storage and for better understanding of the environmental risk due to potential leakage, this induces an urgent need for more mesocosm experiments on the Baltic animals (Havenhand, 2012). In particular, studies using biochemical markers (e.g. high energetic sources, compounds that are involved in cellular defence, stress enzymes) are of interests as they provide clues about immediate physiological responses of an organism to increases in seawater pCO 2 and hypercapnic stress. The responses observed in marine benthic faunal species may also serve as important indicators in future environmental monitoring and early-warning systems for CO 2 leaking from geological storage sites (Ishida et al., 2013) in order to improve the risk assessment and management.

This study aimed at quantification of biochemical responses of the calcifying estuarine bivalve Limecola balthica to medium-term exposure to CO 2 -induced water acidification. The Baltic clam dominates benthic communities in soft-bottom, organic-rich deeper area of the Baltic Sea and can serve therefore as a good model-species. Since the bivalve shows broad tolerance of adverse environmental conditions, including trace metal pollution, oxygen deficit and even temporal presence of hydrogen sulphide (Jahn and Theede, 1997;Sokołowski et al., 2004), its potential to cope with severe seawater acidification was evaluated.

div.p: Collection of materials, their pre-treatment, experimental setup and sampling of bivalves during the exposure to CO 2 -induced declined seawater pH were described in details in Sokołowski et al. (2018) and are presented here only in brief.

div.head: Material collection and pre-treatment
div.p: Surface sediment and the Baltic clams Limecola balthica were sampled at one coastal site (MW; φ 54º37'30.6"N λ 18º37'25.8"E) of 30 m water depth in the Gulf of Gdańsk (southern Baltic Sea) in spring 2014. Sediment was sampled with a Van Veen grab (0.1 m 2 catch surface area) and the upper 10-cm-thick layer was taken with a spatula, stirred and wet sieved through a 1.0-mm mesh to remove macrofauna and large particles. The sediment was then placed in a transporting container and covered with seawater to prevent desiccation and reduce temperature change. The bivalves were collected by dredging and transported to the laboratory in aerated seawater at temperature and salinity corresponding to the ambient environmental situation. In order to reduce the effect of bivalves' size on biochemical responses, only individuals of a restricted shell size range of 11.0-15.0 mm were taken that refers to individuals of 3-4 years old and represents a dominant size class of the local population (Jansen et al., 2007). In addition, samples of overlying bottom seawater (ca. 0.2 m above the sea floor) were collected by means of a 5-dm 3 GoFlo Niskin water sampler to record basic hydrological variables (salinity, temperature, pH and dissolved O 2 ) with a portable WTW Multiset340i meter.

div.head: Experimental set up and sampling protocol
div.p: In the laboratory, bivalves were acclimated to laboratory thermal conditions by increasing seawater temperature from 4.3°C (ambient overlying bottom seawater) to 10.5°C at a rate of 1°C 24 h -1 over six days (Kennedy and Mazursky, 1972). The ambient temperature 4.3°C represents thermal conditions typical for a relatively short cold season (winter-early spring), so water temperature in the experimental system was increased to 10.5°C which occurs in the near-bottom zone under conditions regularly encountered during
div.formula: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 7
div.p: the spring-fall period when phytoplanktonic food supply increases. The clams were then introduced to polystyrene cages (in a form of a cylinder with open top; 7 cm ∅, cm high, 1.2 cm mesh size), 5 individuals each, and allowed to bury in sediments. Cages with sediments (10 cm-thick layer) were placed in 15 plastic buckets (28 cm ∅, 24 cm deep), seven cages per bucket, and the remaining space was then filled with 10 cm-thick sediment and covered with artificial seawater (10 cm). Each bucket contained thus 35 individuals which corresponded to a density of 569 ind. m -2 , i.e. within a range observed on a mid-deep seafloor of the Gulf of Gdańsk (up. to 990 ind. m -2 ; Sokołowski, 2009). The buckets were randomly assigned to 1 of the 3 pH exposure treatments (7.7 -ambient seawater -control treatment, 7.0 and 6.3 corresponding to pCO 2 352 µatm, 1815 µatm and 9150 µatm, respectively) with each treatment containing a total of 175 individuals (five buckets). During the entire experimental period temperature was kept at a constant level 10.5°C. Each of five buckets was supplied independently with artificial seawater (salinity 7.0 PSU) from a separate header tank (200 dm -3 ), via a delivery tube, at a rate of 10 cm 3 min -1 (Fig. 1).

Before seawater acidification started, sediment (without bivalves) was allowed to stabilize in the buckets which were not supplied with seawater for 10 days. Next, bivalves, which showed behavioural activity (e.g. extended either their siphons and/or foot), were added to the cages and acclimated over 31 days at ambient seawater pH 7.7 and constant temperature (10.5°C) (Sgro et al., 2005). The clams were fed once per three days by adding to each bucket 1.5 cm 3 solution of a commercial food KENT MARINE PHYTOPLEX. A feeding dose (yielding final concentration of 0.9 10 9 cell cm -3 72 h -1 ) was proved sufficient to sustain soft tissue weight and growth of L. balthica (Brulińska and Ziółkowska, unpubl. data).

After each bivalve sampling, the amount of feeding solution was reduced proportionally to a decreasing number of animals to maintain a similar food supply per individual throughout the entire experiment. Seawater acidification in the experimental system was induced by passing gaseous carbon dioxide in a form of fine bubbles through artificial seawater in the header tanks using the methods described in Widdicombe and Needham (2007) and Sokołowski et al. (2018). Seawater pH in the tanks was monitored continuously using pH electrodes and

div.head: Monitoring of experimental conditions
div.p: Flow of supply seawater was checked daily and basic hydrological variables (salinity, pH, temperature, dissolved oxygen concentration, total alkalinity (TA; Wolf-Gladrow et al., 2007) and carbonate hardness (KH) were monitored above the sediment in each bucket every three days. In addition, reduction potential was measured in the overlying bottom seawater, and pH and E h were measured in sediment cores at 1 cm intervals on the day of bivalve sampling.

div.head: Biochemical descriptors
div.p: The content of energetic reserves (proteins, lipids and carbohydrates, including glycogen), concentration of heat-shock protein HSP70 (as stress indicator), and biochemical condition index (BCI) were determined as descriptors of biochemical responses of the Baltic clam to seawater acidification induced by CO 2 . Individual shell length of all living individuals on each sampling occasion (0≤ n bucket ≤5) was recorded to the nearest 0.01 mm using a digital calliper. The bivalves were then deshelled, vacuum-dried and weighed to assess individual soft tissue ash dry weight (ADW). Soft tissue of three individuals (n = 3) was subsequently homogenized in a commercial mortar. The protein content was measured according to the Folin-Ciocalteu method of Lowry et al. (1951). Lipids were extracted
div.formula: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 9
div.p: following the chloroform-methanol method of Bligh and Dyer (1959) and measured using a modified method of Marsch and Weinstein (1966). The contents of total carbohydrates and glycogen were determined according to the phenol-sulphuric acid method (Dubois et al., 1956). The content of energetic reserves was expressed in a standard percentage unit of the soft tissue dry weight (% dry wt). The biochemical condition index (BCI) was calculated as the ratio of glycogen content (%) and shell length (cm) (Ellis et al., 2002).

For heat-shock protein HSP70, wet soft tissue of five individuals from each treatment (one individual per bucket on each sampling occasion, n = 5) was weighed and frozen at -80°C until further analysis. Frozen tissues were homogenized in ice-cold phosphate buffer 1PBS (1 g tissue: 10 cm 3 1PBS) and the homogenate was frozen at -24 °C overnight. The homogenate was then thawed and centrifuged (5 min, 5000 RCF at 4 °C) and total HSP70 concentration in each supernatant was measured using a standard Heat shock 70kDa protein ELISA Kit (concentration range 0.156-10.0 ng cm -3 ) following analytical protocol of the producer.

div.head: Statistical analysis
div.p: Untransformed data were included into all statistical models followed by analysis of normality (the Shapiro-Wilk test for goodness of fit) and homogeneity of variances (the Lavene's test) as prerequisites to the parametric approach. The functional relation between pairs of variables was assessed by correlation analysis and the significance of individual differences in length, soft tissue dry weight, biochemical descriptors and HSP70 of the bivalves among pH treatments and sampling occasions was estimated by analysis of variance (ANOVA), and between two variables by paired t-test. When F was significant among treatments the Student-Newman-Keuls (SNK) post-hoc method was used to identify sample means that are significantly different from each other. Due to high variation of the HSP70 individual measurements within a replicated sample (n = 5), the effect of outlying data was down-weighted using the least trimmed squares (LTS) method of Rousseeuw and Leroy (1987). The level of significance for all tests was set as p < 0.05. Statistical analyses were

div.p: carried using Statistica 13.1, USA package for PC. Distance-based linear modelling (DistLM) with Adjusted R 2 selection criterion was performed on biological and hydro-geological data to estimate the variation explained in bivalve responses to low seawater pH accounted for by each seawater and sediment variable. The biological data were square root transformed and submitted to the calculation of Euclidean distance matrices with one dummy variable using procedures in PRIMER 6.0 and its add-on package PERMANOVA+ (Clarke and Gorley, 2006). The direction and magnitude of the relationship among variables and biological responses were depicted in distance-based redundancy analysis (dbRDA) biplots.

div.head: Basic variables of the overlying bottom water and sediment
div.p: Hydrological conditions of the overlying bottom water in the buckets during the experiment were described in detail in Sokołowski et al. (2018). In brief, temperature, salinity, dissolved oxygen concentration and total alkalinity remained stable throughout the entire exposure period and among pH levels (ANOVA). Seawater pH, KH, and reduction potential differed statistically among pH treatments (ANOVA; F 2,465 = 159.2 p < 0.001, F 2,330 = 3.6 p = 0.034 and F 2,44 = 15.3 p < 0.001 for pH, KH and E h , respectively) with the lowest seawater pH and the increased KH under the most acidic conditions. In all treatments, seawater E h was positive with the highest values under control conditions (mean±SE for all sampling occasions; 690 ± 3, n = 14), intermediate measurements in the most acidic treatment (520 ± 46, n = 15), and the lowest records at pH 7.0 (420 ± 7, n = 15) (Tab. 1).

The sediment profiles varied in E h and pH among pH treatments and sediment layers (Tab. 2). Interstitial water in the pH 6.3 treatment showed the highest reduction potential (mean±SE for all layers and sampling occasions; 29 ± 8 mV, n = 114) and pH (7.25 ± 0.03, n = 141), sediments exposed to seawater pH 7.7 had the lowest E h (-5 ± 8 mV, n = 137) and pH (6.89 ± 0.04, n = 168) and those kept at pH 7.0 showed intermediate values

In all pH treatments, E h and pH differed significantly between the top sediment layer (0-1 cm) and the overlying bottom water (paired t-test; t 1,44 = -19.76 p < 0.001 and t 1,95 = -3.24 p = 0.001 for E h and pH, respectively).

Regardless of experimental treatment, the reduction potential of top surface sediments varied from -104 mV to 462 mV (79 ± 12 mV, n = 78) and in most cases (89% of individual records, n = 69) it was < 200 mV, and in 53% of individual records (n = 17) it was below 0 mV. The overlying bottom water E h never fell below 120 mV with maximum 548 mV and mean 334 ± 23 mV (n = 44). The average surface sediment (0-1 cm) interstitial water pH (6.84 ± 0.06, n = 30) exceeded notably that of the overlying water (6.41 ± 0.10, n = 30) under the most acidic conditions (paired t-test; t 1,183 = 6.84 p < 0.001), and it was distinctly lower than water pH under control conditions (6.73 ± 0.04, n = 34 vs. 7.57 ± 0.04, n = 33; paired ttest; t 1,187 = -16.22 p < 0.001). In the pH 7.0 treatment, pH in the surface sediments and overlying water was similar (6.86 ± 0.10, n = 31 vs. 6.96 ± 0.04, n = 35; paired t-test). In all pH treatments, the highest E h was measured in the top-most sediments (0-1 cm) to decrease in the next layer (1-2 cm) and level out in deeper layers (3-5 cm). This general pattern was consistent throughout the entire experiment, but it was most pronounced at the end of the exposure period when E h reached over 200 mV in the pH 7.0 and 7.7 treatments. In contrast, sediment interstitial water pH showed an inverse pattern in all treatments with the lowest values in the top-most layer (0-1 cm) and an increasing trend along sediment profile depth (Tab. 3).

div.head: Energetic resources and BCI
div.p: CO 2 -induced seawater acidification impacted significantly the content of total carbohydrates and glycogen, and the biochemical condition index (BCI), while lipids and proteins in soft tissue of the Baltic clam did not differ among pH treatments. Bivalves kept under the most acidic conditions (pH 6.3) showed elevated levels of total carbohydrates and glycogen (mean±SE for all sampling occasions; 18.9 ± 1.0 % dry wt, n = 21 and 14.3 ± 0.8 % dry wt, n = 21, respectively) while those exposed to seawater pH 7.0 had less store of these M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT biochemical components (15.0 ± 0.8 % dry wt, n = 20 and 10.8 ± 0.7 % dry wt, n = 20, respectively) relative to animals in the control treatment (pH 7.7; 16.8 ± 0.7 % dry wt, n = 23 and 11.6 ± 0.7 % dry wt, n = 23, respectively; Fig. 2). The SNK post-hoc test revealed significant differences in carbohydrates between clams in the 6.3 and 7.0 treatments (p = 0.005) and in glycogen between animals at seawater 6.3 and 7.0 (p = 0.004), and 6.3 and 7.7 (p = 0.013). Since the total shell length and individual soft tissue ash dry weight of L. balthica did not differ among pH treatments (ANOVA), a decreased glycogen content resulted in diminished BCI in animals at seawater pH 7.0 (SNK post-hoc test, p = 0.006 and p = 0.014 between clams at seawater 6.3 and 7.0 and between bivalves at 6.3 and 7.7, respectively; Fig. 3). A similar but not significant pattern was also observed for lipid content with the lowest values in bivalves at seawater pH 7.0 (15.8 ± 0.5 % dry wt, n = 20) and elevated lipid reserves in animals from the pH 6.3 (16.8 ± 0.6 % dry wt, n = 21) and 7.7 treatments (17.3 ± 0.5 % dry wt, n = 23). In contrast, in response to seawater hypercapnia the bivalves increased substantially protein resources, particularly under intermediate pH conditions (pH 7.0) where the clams contained as much as 57.1 ± 1.3 % dry wt (n = 20) proteins (Fig. 2). It is noteworthy that seawater acidified to a pH 7.0 level reduced the sum of all energetic resources measured in the Baltic clams which was markedly lower (87.3 ± 1.4 % dry wt, n = 20) as compared to animals exposed to pH 6.3 (92.0 ± 1.4 % dry wt, n = 21) and to pH 7.7 (89.7 ± 1.1 % dry wt, n = 23), indicating an increased contribution of minerals in the soft tissue. The low sum of all biochemical components in animals from the pH 7.0 conditions was accounted primarily for by decreased contents of carbohydrates (89.6% of the respective mean value in the control treatment) and lipids (91.2%).

All energetic resources of the L. balthica and BCI varied also significantly over time (Tab. 4). Though not statistically significant (correlation analysis between sets of mean values for subsequent sampling occasions), patterns of temporal changes of a given biochemical component were similar across different pH levels, particularly in the pH 6.3 and 7.7 treatments. In the pH 6.0 and 7.7 treatments, the contents of carbohydrates and glycogen dropped substantially after 7 days of exposure following by an increase to a M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 13 maximum value within the next 28 days and a decrease thereafter (Fig. 2). At seawater pH 7.0, soft tissue content of sugars increased slightly during the first 3 days, then decreased until the 7 th day of exposure do rise again over the next 35 days (until 42 d) and drop markedly thereafter (Fig. 2). Clams kept under all pH conditions contained less carbohydrates at the end of the experiment relative to the exposure commencement. Lipid content in bivalve soft tissue increased notably at the beginning of exposure to maxima after 14 days (pH 6.3 and 7.7) or 28 days of the experiment (pH 7.0) and then decreased to higher (by 9.4% and 28.0% at pH 6.3 and 7.0, respectively) or lower values (by 18.1% at pH 7.7) than those which were measured at 0 d. An inverse pattern of temporal variations was evident for protein level which demonstrated two minima: after the first 7 days (pH 7.7) or 14 days (pH 6.3 and 7.0) and then at the very end of the exposure period (after 42 days at pH 6.3 and after 56 days at pH 7.0 and 7.7; Fig. 2).

Seawater acidification exerted also a significant effect on biochemical condition index which varied among pH treatments and over time (Tab. 2). BCI showed a similar trend to those for the soft tissue contents of carbohydrates and glycogen, with increased values in the most acidic environment (mean±SE for all sampling occasions; 10.7 ± 0.6 % cm -1 , n = 21) and low index in the pH 7.0 treatment (8.1 ± 0.6 % cm -1 , n = 20) relative to the control conditions (8.6 ± 0.6 % cm -1 , n = 22). Temporal changes of BCI followed closely a pattern of glycogen (correlation analyses; R = 0.947 p = 0.001, R = 0.950 p = 0.001 and R = 0.975 p < 0.001 in the pH 6.3, 7.0 and 7.7 treatments, respectively). After an initial decrease during the first 7 days of exposure, BCI had risen on 28 d (pH 6.3 and 7.7) or 42 d (pH 7.0) to depress again thereafter (all these being lower than the start controls; Fig. 3).

div.head: HSP70
div.p: The cytosolic heat-shock protein HSP70, which comprise a group of highly conserved proteins that have general protective function in all living organisms (Hofmann, 1999), showed no significant differences either among different pH treatments or time points (Tab.

2). The HSP70 concentration tended to increase, however, with seawater acidity reaching a M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT maximum value (mean±SE; 6.03 ± 0.35 ng cm -3 , n = 37) in the most acidic environment.

Under all experimental conditions the HSP70 level in bivalve soft tissues increased on 3 d. At seawater pH 7.7 and 7.0, it then dropped after the next 11 days of exposure (14 d) to increase again on 42 d and fall thereafter. In the pH 6.3 treatment, after the initial 3 d-rise, HSP70 concentration increased further up on 14 d and lowered gradually over the remaining period (Fig. 3).

div.head: Effect of seawater hypercapnia on energetic reserves
div.p: According to the conceptual sequence of response of marine organisms to changes in environmental conditions at different levels of biological organization (molecular, cellular, whole-organism and population), stress-induced disturbances in the organismal energy budget (including main energetic resources) is a sum of cellular stress responses (Harvey et al., 2014). Phenotypic effects at the whole-organism level occur, however, later after changes at the genomic and biochemical level (e.g. alterations in metabolic enzyme activities) are observed. For instance, Kaniewska et al. (2012) reported changes in gene expression and cell physiology far before a decrease in calcification rates (phenotypic effect) was noticed in the reef-building coral Acropora millepora in response to seawater acidification. Shifts in the gross energetic resources (carbohydrates, lipids and proteins) are thus a consequence of the immediate biochemical reactions (e.g. enzymatic protein activity) but can also reflect far-reaching and serious organism disruption resulting in altered energy reallocation in response to stress. On longer time scales (days-weeks), such shifts might lead to reduction in organism performance (e.g., reduced growth rate and development) and even to death if environmental perturbations are in excess of organisms' tolerance limit.

In this study, the infaunal Baltic clams Limecola balthica were exposed to acidification within seawater pH range of 6.3 -7.7 (control) to simulate changes in the overlying bottom water after the potential CO 2 leakage from the geological sub-seabed storage site in the

div.p: southern Baltic Sea. Although interstitial water pH was similar across all treatments throughout most experiment and independent to a certain degree of the target seawater pH above the sediment surface (Table 3), the bivalves were directly impacted by the acidic conditions through their ventilation and feeding behaviours (Zwarts and Wanink, 1989).

Limecola balthica lives preferentially burrowed in sediments and utilizes its long extensible siphons to pump water and vacuum particles from the overlying water via gill ciliary action across the gills, through the mantle cavity and out the exhalant siphon. Both inhalant and exhalant siphons of the Baltic clams were observed in all pH treatments throughout the entire experiment, indicating active water pumping and filtration (author's own observation). Such an action enables access to oxygen and/or food and simultaneously limits exposure of the bivalves to the interstitial water, while supporting both feeding and respiration. For example, the bent-nosed clam Macoma nasuta was estimated to ventilate only approximately 10 % pore water even when its siphons are retracted inside their burrow (Winsor et al., 1990).

pH CO 2 -induced seawater acidification exerted a significant effect on carbohydrates and glycogen (and BCI), i.e. energy sources with relatively fast metabolic turnover which are used to meet enhanced energy demands, e.g. during poor nutritional conditions or environmental stress (Wołowicz et al., 2006). The low carbohydrates and glycogen contents of soft tissue ash dry weight of Limecola balthica in the pH 7.0 treatment as compared to the bivalves kept at seawater pH 6.3 and 7.7 indicate worse performance of the former. Though not significant, a similar U-shape pattern with apparently lowered values under moderate hypercapnic conditions was also observed for lipids (Fig. 2) which constitute the principal energy reserves in bivalves (Zandee et al. 1980). A decreased storage of caloric reserves resulted inevitably from their catabolism in order to cover increased metabolic requirements in defensive/compensatory reaction to moderate seawater acidity. A decline in glycogen content was also found in the mantle tissue of oyster Crassostrea gigas during long-term moderate exposure to pCO 2 ~ 150 Pa (Lannig et al., 2010). Intra-and extracellular acid-base regulation and buffering of free protons in body fluids are well-known mechanisms of pH compensation in marine bivalves (Melzner et al., 2009) which incur substantial physiological

div.head: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
div.p: and energetic costs (Schade et al., 2016). When increased energy demands on defence are in excess of available reserves and energy acquisition from food, this can cause the death of an organism (Bayne and Newell, 1983) as shown by a decreased survival rate of L. balthica at lower seawater pH (Sokołowski et al., 2018). Under conditions of permanent and sufficient food supply, elevated energy expenditure of the Baltic clam on counteracting acidosis and maintenance of internal acid-balance at seawater pH 7.0 is covered by energy acquisition from phytoplanktonic food (Sokołowski et al., 2018) and a simultaneous breakdown of energetic reserves. Enhanced catabolism of energetic resources was also indicated by a loss of individual soft tissue ash dry weight of bivalves from the 7.0 treatment (on average by ca. 5.3%) relative to the control clams (Sokołowski et al., 2018). It is noteworthy that exposure to seawater pH 7.0 imposed a simultaneous increase of the protein content, a pattern which is in stark contrast to most invertebrate studies on pH physiological regulatory mechanisms (e.g. Donohue et al., 2012). Proteins serve as an important intracellular non-bicarbonate buffer (Thomsen and Melzner, 2010) and contribute to oxygen transport in haemolymph in marine and coastal molluscs (e.g. Pörtner et al., 2008;Melzner et al., 2009). Increased breakdown of proteins and/or reduced rate of protein synthesis occurs thus often in hypercapnic bivalves which shift from carbohydrate/lipid-based energy metabolism to amino acid catabolism (Zhao et al., 2017). Such a reduction of proteins under acidic conditions was reported, for example, in the clam Ruditapes decussatus from the Ria Formosa shallow lagoon on the Atlantic coast of Portugal (Range et al., 2014) and in the blood clam Tegillarca granosa from the Yueqing Bay, China (Zhao et al., 2017). On the other hand, Matozzo et al. (2012) observed increased protein levels in haemolymph of the clam Chamelea gallina and the mussel Mytilus galloprovincialis exposed to lowered pH (8.1-control, 7.7 and 7.4) and suggested that it could be related to modifications of serum components, i.e. activation of certain enzymes and/or proteins released from haemocytes into the haemolymph under acidic stress. Further study on activity of enzymes, which are involved in metabolic and defensive processes such as oxygen metabolism, antioxidative defence, acid-based balance and neurotransmission, is needed, however, to corroborate this hypothesis.

div.p: Another plausible explanation is that moderate hypercapnia impacted the clams only to a limited extent, indicating broad tolerance of the bivalves to seawater acidification.

Support to this hypothesis is provided by the fact that the observed changes of carbohydrates, lipids and proteins due to exposure to lower seawater pH fall into a relatively narrow range (max/min of mean values for all pH treatments; 1.3, 1.1 and 1.0, respectively) which is within natural seasonal variation of these resources that are observed in L. balthica in the southern Baltic Sea (2.6, 1.5 and 2.1, respectively; Sokołowski, 1999). Such small variations in the soft tissue protein (1.1) and glycogen (1.4÷2.8) contents were also found in the same clam species after short-term experimental exposure to elevated dissolved Cu concentration (Sokołowski et al., 1999). The bivalves are therefore expected to have a certain level of pre-adaptation to adverse environmental conditions, including trace metal contamination (Sokołowski et al., 1999) and acidification (Sokołowski et al., 2018). Owing to high natural interstitial water pH variability in organic-rich surface sediments of the Baltic (down to pH 7.0; Jansson et al., 2016), which is related organic matter mineralization, the bivalves experience likely acidified conditions during their larval and/or ontogenic life stages, allowing to develop efficient defensive/compensatory mechanisms towards high environmental pCO 2 . Pre-adaptation through lifestyle and/or ontogeny was proposed as an explanatory hypothesis of low sensitivity of selected marine faunal species to seawater acidification in extensive review by Melzner et al., (2009). Based on experimental study Talmage and Gobler (2010) suggested that pre-adaptive mechanism accounted for greater growth and survival and greater percentage metamorphosis of larvae of the hard clam Mercenaria mercenaria and the bay scallop Argopecten irradians after exposure to the elevated CO 2 level (1500 ppm). According to Parker et al. (2013) such a pre-adaptation of some marine mollusc species to reduced seawater pH can undergo based on either evolutionary adaptation or environmental phenotypic plasticity within a generation (acclimation). Indeed, Thomsen and Melzner (2010) found that long-term acclimation to elevated environmental pCO2 increases the ability to calcify in the mussel Mytilus spp. from the Kiel Fjord in the western Baltic Sea. Similarly, Schade et al. (2017)

Organic matter oxidation under reducing conditions was evidenced by low E h in the sediments (even down to -112 mV) but it did not lead to CO 2 reduction (and the consequent formation of methane) as shown by only slight changes in interstitial water pH (6.9-7.8). Such surface sediment profiles reflect well the environmental situation in muddy and sandy-muddy stratified areas of the southern Baltic Sea where oxic decomposition of organic matter occurs only in the uppermost layer (mm-cm thick) (Lukawska-Matuszewska and Kielczewska, 2016).

Similar conditions were also observed in sediments in the area of the potential CO 2 subseabed storage site in the Baltic (B3 field) in September 2012 when total alkalinity and concentrations of H 2 S, SO 4 −2 and NH 4 + increased with sediment depth indicating advanced mineralization processes in deeper layers (ECO2, 2014).

Interestingly, adverse impact of seawater acidification on energetic reserves of L. balthica was less detrimental in the most acidic environment (pH 6.3; Fig. 2) than at moderate seawater pH (7.0) suggesting a CO 2 -threshold concentration between 1815 µatm and 9150 µatm. Together with a different pattern of soft tissue protein content, this locates the clam in a somehow unique position with regard to most ecological studies on invertebrate response to severe hypercapnia (e.g., Ries et al., 2009;Sokołowski et al., 2018). Because chemoautotrophy is very demanding of oxygen, the host bivalves sustain high rates of oxygen uptake from the overlying bottom water and high rates of oxygen transport to the symbionts (Childress and Girguis, 2011). Owing to the presence of endosymbiotic bacteria the bivalves can withstand decreased seawater pH under anoxic conditions and maintain basic physiological processes at a rate similar to that which is observed in bivalves in the normoxic environments.

It has been shown that in response to the low interstitial water oxygen concentration, the Baltic clams move vertically toward the sediment surface and extend their syphons high above the sediments (Sokołowski et al., 2008). Heat shock proteins, including HSP70, are among the most abundant intracellular proteins protecting cells from stress-induced damage by promoting protein folding, membrane translocation, degradation of misfolded proteins and maintenance of cellular homeostasis(Liu and Chen, 2013). ConclusionsSeawater acidification in a range which simulated changes in acidity of the overlying bottom water after potential carbon dioxide leakage from the sub-seabed CCS site disrupted gross energy metabolism of the Baltic clam Limecola balthica only under the moderate hypercapnic conditions (pH 7.0) while no clear effect was evident at seawater pH 6.3. The modest acidic environment (pH 7.0) induced elevated catabolism of high caloric reserves of fast metabolic turnover (carbohydrates including glycogen and partly lipids) in order to provide additional energy to cover enhanced metabolic requirements for acid-base regulation. Increased metabolism of the bivalves did not involve, however, breakdown of proteins, suggesting that amino acids and proteins were not used as metabolic substrates. The clams demonstrated thus broad tolerance and large pre-adapted capacity for seawater acidification through development of efficient defensive/compensatory mechanisms of acute acidosis as indicated also by subtle variations in the chaperone protein HSP70
